ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
- learned a lot about German history, particularly the Kaiserreich and the Weimar Republic
- improved understanding of relative pronouns
- improved presentation skills and oral confidence

The class improves your ability to analyze films and texts in German and gives you the vocabulary to feel confident doing so. The class also gives a good introduction to the major historical and political movements in Germany during the 19th century.
I have learnt more of the pre-1945 German history and deepened my German skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
- learning about the Weimar republic through the lens of a genuinely fun-to-watch TV show made the class quite enjoyable during that period

Weaknesses:
- homework was too much for the first half of the semester
- classes lacked much energy or excitement, fairly repetitive

Instead of having the Babylon Berlin episode discussions dominated by two people in each class, I think it would be good to open the discussions to everyone as was the case in the first half of the semester, and not have presentations.

We wasted so much time on Babylon Berlin. It consumed nearly half the semester. The second season was excessive, and the third season was completely unnecessary. I think in the future a better format would be to have students watch only the first season at home and spend only 2-3 classes discussing the entire season. German history and culture are so interesting. It was unfortunate to restrict our study of it to the few themes explored in the tv series. 

We didnt study what was arguably the most important and consequential period of German History 1933-1945. Missing out on such a pivotal period was a big failing of this class. 

Each paper has an early deadline which you can use to submit a first draft and receive feedback before submitting the final draft. I appreciated this feature of the class. 

Marion is another big strength of this class. She is a kind and thoughtful instructor and provides ample feedback to help improve your ability as a German speaker.
I wish we had more of actual linguistic engagement with other students, such as dialogues and open discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I wouldn't recommend this course. I would tell other students that the Babylon Berlin section of the course is fun, but the other sections are less engaging. I'd tell them that if they want to keep their German at a certain standard then this course could be an option, but that there might be other more engaging German courses  out there too.
Yes! This class gives a good introduction to the major historical and political movements in Germany during the 19th century and an opportunity to improve your German.
I would recommend the course to those interested in history and German. Otherwise, students might find the historical focus challenging or boring to them.
